item.title: Mid-Side
item.description: Description: One Cardioid (Mid) and one figure-8 (Side) microphone, with the Side mic capturing left/right differences. Impossible to record an uneven stereo image The 'Mid' and the 'Side' channels can be treated with different equalisation and compression. Solidify the centre. Add sparkle to the stereo. The balance between the mono central image and the side/stereo width can be adjusted after recording. item.title: SSL Bus +
item.description: Location: Paragon Purpose: Compression and Transient Designing Try it on everything. This is a classy unit that will let you understand the difference between analogue and digital processing. Eventide Propaganda: We've been on a mission to create the ultimate and most versatile incarnation of the Bus Compressor ever. The bedrock of the design remains faithful to the original circuit and using this as the foundation, we've built upon it, adding several unique colouration options and advanced processing tools. If you need it to be clean and punchy like the SuperAnalogueTM 9000 Series version, it can be. If you need it to be gritty and grungy like an early 4000E, it can do that also. Or if you need over-the-top, saturated, parallel compression for the drums, THE BUS+ has got you covered. THE BUS+ circuit design utilises high-grade components, including 2181 THAT VCAs for superior analogue performance, four modes of operation and 3 distinct compression colouration options which can be combined to perfectly suit the genre you‚Äôre working on. THE BUS+ also packs in sophisticated routing options and advanced processing tools: Dynamic Equaliser (D-EQ), Transient Expander and so much more‚Ä¶ SSL Website

item.title: XY (Coincident Pair)
item.description: Configuration:: 2 CardioidAngle:: 90¬∞Spacing:: 0 cm (Capsules Touching)Strengths:: Good mono compatibility, balanced stereo imageWeaknesses:: Narrow stereo widthDescription: Two directional microphones (usually cardioid) placed at a 90¬∞ angle, capsules as close together as possible.Tips for Competency: ‚úî Ensure capsules are as close as possible to avoid phase issues. ‚úî Best for mono compatibility and capturing a balanced stereo image. ‚úî Works well for small ensembles and close-miked sources. ‚úî Avoid excessive spacing between mics‚Äîuse a stereo bar for precision.90¬∫135¬∫XY - Coincident Pair `

item.title: Spaced Pair AB
item.description: (A/B)Description: Two omnidirectional microphones spaced apart, often 40 cm to 1 m or more.Tips for Competency: ‚úî Best for capturing a wide, immersive stereo image. ‚úî Be aware of phase issues‚Äîcheck the 3:1 rule (space mics three times the distance from the source). ‚úî Works well for room ambiance, large ensembles, and drum overheads. ‚úî Requires careful positioning to avoid excessive hole-in-the-middle effect.

item.title: OSS
item.description: OSS (Optimised Stereo Signal) / Jecklin DiskDescription: Two omnidirectional microphones placed 17 cm apart, with an acoustic baffle (disk) between them to enhance spatial separation and reduce phase issues.Tips for Competency: ‚úî Ensure precise spacing‚Äî17 cm between mics and a properly designed disk (approx. 35 cm in diameter with sound-absorbing material). ‚úî Positioning matters‚Äîkeep the disk perpendicular to the sound source for an accurate stereo image. ‚úî Best for natural stereo depth in acoustic and classical recordings. ‚úî Avoid using in close-mic setups‚Äîthis technique works best in well-balanced environments with natural reverb. ‚úî Use quality omnidirectional mics to capture a smooth frequency response.

item.title: NOS
item.description: (Near-Coincident)Description: Two cardioid microphones at a 90¬∞ angle, spaced 30 cm apart.Tips for Competency: ‚úî Offers a wider stereo field than ORTF but less localization accuracy. ‚úî Good for capturing broader ensembles and natural reverb. ‚úî Ensure proper spacing to avoid excessive phase issues. ‚úî Works well for classical music, chamber ensembles, and field recordings.

item.title: ORTF
item.description: (Near-Coincident)Description: Two cardioid microphones at a 110¬∞ angle, spaced 17 cm apart.Tips for Competency: ‚úî Provides a natural stereo image with good spatial accuracy. ‚úî Use a mic bar with pre-measured spacing for accuracy. ‚úî Works well for orchestras, choirs, and ambient recordings. ‚úî Be mindful of room reflections affecting stereo width.

item.title: Faulkner Array
item.description: Description: Two figure-8 microphones spaced about 20 cm apart.Tips for Competency: ‚úî Balances stereo width and natural tonal capture. ‚úî Works well for choirs, orchestras, and chamber music. ‚úî Be mindful of room reflections affecting stereo accuracy. ‚úî Avoid excessive spacing to prevent a weak center image.

item.title: Decca Tree
item.description: Description: Three omnidirectional microphones (one center, two spaced apart), often used in orchestral recording.Tips for Competency: ‚úî Best for capturing full orchestras with depth and spaciousness. ‚úî Requires a large space and precise positioning for optimal results. ‚úî Works well when combined with spot mics for clarity. ‚úî Experiment with center mic height to balance direct and ambient sound.

item.title: EBS
item.description: (Equal Brilliance Stereo) Description: Two cardioid microphones positioned at a 90¬∞ angle, spaced 25 cm apart. This technique is designed to maintain equal brilliance across the stereo field, providing a balanced frequency response while preserving stereo width and localisation.Tips for Competency: ‚úî Ensure precise spacing‚Äî25 cm between microphone capsules to achieve optimal stereo imaging. ‚úî Use high-quality cardioid microphones to capture a detailed, focused stereo field. ‚úî Best for small ensembles, solo instruments, and speech recordings where natural tonal balance is important. ‚úî Test different angles and placements based on room acoustics to prevent excessive phase issues. ‚úî Avoid excessive off-axis colouration‚Äîpositioning the microphones at the correct 90¬∞ angle ensures an even frequency response across the stereo image.https://sengpielaudio.com/EBS-StereoSystemEnglish.htm

item.title: Binaural
item.description: Description: Omnidirectional microphones placed in ear-shaped cavities on a dummy head.Tips for Competency: ‚úî Best for headphone playback, creating an immersive 3D soundstage. ‚úî Works well for ASMR, field recording, and experimental music. ‚úî Positioning is crucial‚Äîrecord at head height for realism. ‚úî Not ideal for speaker playback due to exaggerated stereo width.

item.title: Blumlein Pair
item.description: Description: Two figure-8 microphones at a 90¬∞ angle, coincident placement.Tips for Competency: ‚úî Captures a highly immersive stereo image with natural depth. ‚úî Works well in well-treated or acoustically pleasing rooms. ‚úî Be mindful of sound reflections from the back lobes of the mics. ‚úî Ideal for solo instruments, duets, and small ensembles.Alan Lived in Ealing0¬∫90¬∫180¬∫270¬∫

item.title: Omnidirectional
item.description: 0¬∫90¬∫180¬∫270¬∫ Captures sound equally from all directions (360¬∞ around the microphone). No proximity effect, making it ideal for natural-sounding recordings. More resistant to wind noise and plosives compared to directional mics. Typically provides a flatter frequency response than directional microphones. ‚úî Studio recording ‚Äì Used for capturing natural room ambiance. ‚úî Lavalier microphones ‚Äì Frequently used in TV, theater, and interviews. ‚úî Classical music recording ‚Äì Often used in orchestral and choir recordings to preserve natural room acoustics. ‚úî Boundary microphones ‚Äì Used on conference tables or in stage performances. The first microphones were naturally omnidirectional until engineers developed directional designs. Omnidirectional microphones work well underwater and are used in hydrophones for underwater recordings. Many lavalier (clip-on) microphones are omnidirectional to capture speech without worrying about mic positioning.

item.title: Figure-Of-Eight
item.description: 0¬∫90¬∫180¬∫270¬∫ Picks up sound equally from the front and rear, while rejecting sound from the sides. Exhibits the strongest proximity effect of all polar patterns. Common in ribbon microphones and some large-diaphragm condensers. More susceptible to off-axis coloration, meaning sound sources must be well-positioned. ‚úî Studio recording ‚Äì Used for stereo recording techniques (Mid-Side and Blumlein pair). ‚úî Podcasting & interviews ‚Äì Allows two people to speak into the same mic from opposite sides. ‚úî Live sound for acoustic instruments ‚Äì Captures both the instrument and room reflections for a natural feel. ‚úî Broadcasting ‚Äì Used in some radio stations where announcers face each other. The first-ever microphones (carbon microphones) had a figure-of-eight pattern. Ribbon microphones, like the Royer R-121, naturally have a figure-of-eight pattern due to their ribbon diaphragm design. The Blumlein stereo technique, invented by Alan Blumlein, uses two figure-of-eight microphones at 90¬∞ to each other to create a realistic stereo image.

item.title: Cardioid
item.description: 0¬∫90¬∫180¬∫270¬∫ The cardioid pattern gets its name from its heart-shaped pickup pattern. It captures sound predominantly from the front, while rejecting most sound from the rear. Offers moderate rejection of sound from the sides. It exhibits the proximity effect, meaning that the bass response increases as the sound source gets closer to the microphone. ‚úî Live sound reinforcement ‚Äì Common in vocal mics to reduce feedback from stage monitors. ‚úî Recording studios ‚Äì Ideal for isolating vocals or instruments by reducing background noise. ‚úî Broadcasting & podcasting ‚Äì Helps eliminate room noise and reflections. ‚úî Close-miking ‚Äì Used for individual instruments in loud environments (e.g., drum kits, guitar amps). The Shure SM58, one of the most famous microphones in the world, has a cardioid pattern. The proximity effect can be used creatively by singers and voiceover artists to enhance the low-end warmth of their voice. Supercardioid and hypercardioid patterns are tighter variations of cardioid, offering more directionality but picking up some sound from the rear.

item.title: OSS
item.description: OSS (Optimised Stereo Signal) / Jecklin DiskDescription: Two omnidirectional microphones placed 17 cm apart, with an acoustic baffle (disk) between them to enhance spatial separation and reduce phase issues.Tips for Competency: ‚úî Ensure precise spacing‚Äî17 cm between mics and a properly designed disk (approx. 35 cm in diameter with sound-absorbing material). ‚úî Positioning matters‚Äîkeep the disk perpendicular to the sound source for an accurate stereo image. ‚úî Best for natural stereo depth in acoustic and classical recordings. ‚úî Avoid using in close-mic setups‚Äîthis technique works best in well-balanced environments with natural reverb. ‚úî Use quality omnidirectional mics to capture a smooth frequency response.

item.title: NOS
item.description: (Near-Coincident)Description: Two cardioid microphones at a 90¬∞ angle, spaced 30 cm apart.Tips for Competency: ‚úî Offers a wider stereo field than ORTF but less localization accuracy. ‚úî Good for capturing broader ensembles and natural reverb. ‚úî Ensure proper spacing to avoid excessive phase issues. ‚úî Works well for classical music, chamber ensembles, and field recordings.

item.title: ORTF
item.description: (Near-Coincident)Description: Two cardioid microphones at a 110¬∞ angle, spaced 17 cm apart.Tips for Competency: ‚úî Provides a natural stereo image with good spatial accuracy. ‚úî Use a mic bar with pre-measured spacing for accuracy. ‚úî Works well for orchestras, choirs, and ambient recordings. ‚úî Be mindful of room reflections affecting stereo width.

item.title: Faulkner Array
item.description: Description: Two figure-8 microphones spaced about 20 cm apart.Tips for Competency: ‚úî Balances stereo width and natural tonal capture. ‚úî Works well for choirs, orchestras, and chamber music. ‚úî Be mindful of room reflections affecting stereo accuracy. ‚úî Avoid excessive spacing to prevent a weak center image.

item.title: Decca Tree
item.description: Description: Three omnidirectional microphones (one center, two spaced apart), often used in orchestral recording.Tips for Competency: ‚úî Best for capturing full orchestras with depth and spaciousness. ‚úî Requires a large space and precise positioning for optimal results. ‚úî Works well when combined with spot mics for clarity. ‚úî Experiment with center mic height to balance direct and ambient sound.

item.title: EBS
item.description: (Equal Brilliance Stereo) Description: Two cardioid microphones positioned at a 90¬∞ angle, spaced 25 cm apart. This technique is designed to maintain equal brilliance across the stereo field, providing a balanced frequency response while preserving stereo width and localisation.Tips for Competency: ‚úî Ensure precise spacing‚Äî25 cm between microphone capsules to achieve optimal stereo imaging. ‚úî Use high-quality cardioid microphones to capture a detailed, focused stereo field. ‚úî Best for small ensembles, solo instruments, and speech recordings where natural tonal balance is important. ‚úî Test different angles and placements based on room acoustics to prevent excessive phase issues. ‚úî Avoid excessive off-axis colouration‚Äîpositioning the microphones at the correct 90¬∞ angle ensures an even frequency response across the stereo image.https://sengpielaudio.com/EBS-StereoSystemEnglish.htm

item.title: Binaural
item.description: Description: Omnidirectional microphones placed in ear-shaped cavities on a dummy head.Tips for Competency: ‚úî Best for headphone playback, creating an immersive 3D soundstage. ‚úî Works well for ASMR, field recording, and experimental music. ‚úî Positioning is crucial‚Äîrecord at head height for realism. ‚úî Not ideal for speaker playback due to exaggerated stereo width.

item.title: Blumlein Pair
item.description: Description: Two figure-8 microphones at a 90¬∞ angle, coincident placement.Tips for Competency: ‚úî Captures a highly immersive stereo image with natural depth. ‚úî Works well in well-treated or acoustically pleasing rooms. ‚úî Be mindful of sound reflections from the back lobes of the mics. ‚úî Ideal for solo instruments, duets, and small ensembles.Alan Lived in Ealing0¬∫90¬∫180¬∫270¬∫

item.title: Omnidirectional
item.description: 0¬∫90¬∫180¬∫270¬∫ Captures sound equally from all directions (360¬∞ around the microphone). No proximity effect, making it ideal for natural-sounding recordings. More resistant to wind noise and plosives compared to directional mics. Typically provides a flatter frequency response than directional microphones. ‚úî Studio recording ‚Äì Used for capturing natural room ambiance. ‚úî Lavalier microphones ‚Äì Frequently used in TV, theater, and interviews. ‚úî Classical music recording ‚Äì Often used in orchestral and choir recordings to preserve natural room acoustics. ‚úî Boundary microphones ‚Äì Used on conference tables or in stage performances. The first microphones were naturally omnidirectional until engineers developed directional designs. Omnidirectional microphones work well underwater and are used in hydrophones for underwater recordings. Many lavalier (clip-on) microphones are omnidirectional to capture speech without worrying about mic positioning.

item.title: Figure-Of-Eight
item.description: 0¬∫90¬∫180¬∫270¬∫ Picks up sound equally from the front and rear, while rejecting sound from the sides. Exhibits the strongest proximity effect of all polar patterns. Common in ribbon microphones and some large-diaphragm condensers. More susceptible to off-axis coloration, meaning sound sources must be well-positioned. ‚úî Studio recording ‚Äì Used for stereo recording techniques (Mid-Side and Blumlein pair). ‚úî Podcasting & interviews ‚Äì Allows two people to speak into the same mic from opposite sides. ‚úî Live sound for acoustic instruments ‚Äì Captures both the instrument and room reflections for a natural feel. ‚úî Broadcasting ‚Äì Used in some radio stations where announcers face each other. The first-ever microphones (carbon microphones) had a figure-of-eight pattern. Ribbon microphones, like the Royer R-121, naturally have a figure-of-eight pattern due to their ribbon diaphragm design. The Blumlein stereo technique, invented by Alan Blumlein, uses two figure-of-eight microphones at 90¬∞ to each other to create a realistic stereo image.

item.title: Cardioid
item.description: 0¬∫90¬∫180¬∫270¬∫ The cardioid pattern gets its name from its heart-shaped pickup pattern. It captures sound predominantly from the front, while rejecting most sound from the rear. Offers moderate rejection of sound from the sides. It exhibits the proximity effect, meaning that the bass response increases as the sound source gets closer to the microphone. ‚úî Live sound reinforcement ‚Äì Common in vocal mics to reduce feedback from stage monitors. ‚úî Recording studios ‚Äì Ideal for isolating vocals or instruments by reducing background noise. ‚úî Broadcasting & podcasting ‚Äì Helps eliminate room noise and reflections. ‚úî Close-miking ‚Äì Used for individual instruments in loud environments (e.g., drum kits, guitar amps). The Shure SM58, one of the most famous microphones in the world, has a cardioid pattern. The proximity effect can be used creatively by singers and voiceover artists to enhance the low-end warmth of their voice. Supercardioid and hypercardioid patterns are tighter variations of cardioid, offering more directionality but picking up some sound from the rear.
